title: Installing packages not yet on pip as wheels
Many, pure python, packages are not yet available on the Python Package Index as wheels but still install fine. However, some packages on Windows give the dreaded vcvarsall.bat not found error.

inline_content.Text: Many, pure python, packages are not yet available on the Python Package Index as wheels but still install fine. However, some packages on Windows give the dreaded vcvarsall.bat not found error.

title: The problem is that the package that you are trying to install contains a C or C++ extension and is not
currently
i
available as a pre-built wheel from the python package index,
pypi
i
, and on windows you do not have the tool chain needed to build such items.

inline_content.Text: The problem is that the package that you are trying to install contains a C or C++ extension and is not
available as a pre-built wheel from the python package index,
, and on windows you do not have the tool chain needed to build such items.

title: The simplest answer is to go to
Christoph Gohlke’s
a
http://www.lfd.uci.edu/~gohlke/pythonlibs/
excellent site and locate the
appropriate
b
version of the libraries that you need. By appropriate in the package name a
-cp
b
NN
b
i
b
has to match your version of python, i.e. if you are using windows 32 bit python
even on win64
i
the name must include
-win32-
b
and if using the 64 bit python it must include
-win_amd64-
b
and then the python version must match, i.e. for Python 34 the filename
must
b
include
-cp
b
b
i
, etc. this is basically the magic that pip does for you on the pypi site.

inline_content.Text: The simplest answer is to go to
version of the libraries that you need. By appropriate in the package name a
has to match your version of python, i.e. if you are using windows 32 bit python
and if using the 64 bit python it must include
and then the python version must match, i.e. for Python 34 the filename
, etc. this is basically the magic that pip does for you on the pypi site.

title: Alternatively, you need to get the appropriate windows development kit for the version of python that you are using, the headers for any library that the package you are trying to build interfaces to, possibly the python headers for the version of python, etc.

inline_content.Text: Alternatively, you need to get the appropriate windows development kit for the version of python that you are using, the headers for any library that the package you are trying to build interfaces to, possibly the python headers for the version of python, etc.

title: Python 2.7 used Visual Studio 2008, Python 3.3 and 3.4 used Visual Studio 2010, and Python 3.5+ uses Visual Studio 2015.

inline_content.Text: Python 2.7 used Visual Studio 2008, Python 3.3 and 3.4 used Visual Studio 2010, and Python 3.5+ uses Visual Studio 2015.

title: Install “
Visual C++ Compiler Package for Python 2.7
a
https://www.microsoft.com/en-gb/download/details.aspx?id=44266
”, which is available from Microsoft’s website
or
b

inline_content.Text: Visual C++ Compiler Package for Python 2.7
”, which is available from Microsoft’s website

title: Install “
Windows SDK for Windows 7 and .NET Framework 4
a
https://www.microsoft.com/en-gb/download/details.aspx?id=8279
” (v7.1), which is available from Microsoft’s website
or
b

inline_content.Text: Windows SDK for Windows 7 and .NET Framework 4
” (v7.1), which is available from Microsoft’s website

title: Install
Visual Studio 2015 Community Edition
a
https://www.visualstudio.com/en-us/downloads/download-visual-studio-vs.aspx
(or any later version, when these are released)
i
ensuring you select the options to install C & C++ support
b
no longer the default
i
I am told that this can take up to
i
8 hours
b
i
to download and install so make
sure
b
that those options are set on the first try.

inline_content.Text: (or any later version, when these are released)
ensuring you select the options to install C & C++ support
I am told that this can take up to
to download and install so make
that those options are set on the first try.

title: Then
b
you
may need
i
to locate the header files,
at the matching revision
i
for any libraries that your desired package links to and download those to an appropriate locations.

inline_content.Text: for any libraries that your desired package links to and download those to an appropriate locations.

title: Finally
b
you can let pip do your build - of course if the package has dependencies that you don’t yet have you may also need to find the header files for them as well.

inline_content.Text: you can let pip do your build - of course if the package has dependencies that you don’t yet have you may also need to find the header files for them as well.

title: Alternatives:
b
It is also worth looking out,
both on pypi or Christop’s site
i

, for any slightly earlier version of the package that you are looking for that is either pure python or pre-built for your platform and python version and possibly using those, if found, until your package does become available. Likewise if you are using the very latest version of python you may find that it takes the package maintainers a little time to catch up so for projects that really
need
b

a specific package you may have to use a slightly older python for the moment. You can also check the packages source site to see if there is a forked version that is available pre-built or as pure python and searching for alternative packages that provide the functionality that you require but are available - one example that springs to mind is the
Pillow
a
https://pypi.python.org/pypi/Pillow/3.4.2
actively maintained
i
, drop in replacement for
PIL
a
https://pypi.python.org/pypi/PIL/1.1.6
currently not updated in 6 years and not available for python 3
i

inline_content.Text: It is also worth looking out,
both on pypi or Christop’s site

, for any slightly earlier version of the package that you are looking for that is either pure python or pre-built for your platform and python version and possibly using those, if found, until your package does become available. Likewise if you are using the very latest version of python you may find that it takes the package maintainers a little time to catch up so for projects that really

currently not updated in 6 years and not available for python 3

title: Afterword
b
, I would encourage anybody who is having this problem to go to the bug tracker for the package and add to, or raise if there isn’t one already, a ticket
politely
b

requesting that the package maintainers provide a wheel on pypi for your specific combination of platform and python, if this is done then normally things will get better with time, some package maintainers don’t realise that they have missed a given combination that people may be using.

inline_content.Text: , I would encourage anybody who is having this problem to go to the bug tracker for the package and add to, or raise if there isn’t one already, a ticket

requesting that the package maintainers provide a wheel on pypi for your specific combination of platform and python, if this is done then normally things will get better with time, some package maintainers don’t realise that they have missed a given combination that people may be using.

title: Pip follows the rules of
Semantic Versioning
a
http://semver.org/
and by default prefers released packages over pre-releases. So if a given package has been released as
V0.98
c
and there is also a release candidate
V1.0-rc1
c
the default behaviour of
pip install
c
will be to install
V0.98
c
- if you wish to install the release candidate,
you are advised to test in a virtual environment first
i
, you can enable do so with
--pip install --pre
c
package-name
i
or
--pip install --pre --upgrade
c
package-name
i
. In many cases pre-releases or release candidates may not have wheels built for all platform & version combinations so you are more likely to encounter the issues above.

inline_content.Text: and by default prefers released packages over pre-releases. So if a given package has been released as
and there is also a release candidate
- if you wish to install the release candidate,
you are advised to test in a virtual environment first
, you can enable do so with
. In many cases pre-releases or release candidates may not have wheels built for all platform & version combinations so you are more likely to encounter the issues above.

title: You can also use pip to install development versions of packages from github and other locations, since such code is in flux it is very unlikely to have wheels built for it, so any impure packages will require the presence of the build tools, and they may be broken at any time so the user is
strongly
b
encouraged to only install such packages in a virtual environment.

inline_content.Text: You can also use pip to install development versions of packages from github and other locations, since such code is in flux it is very unlikely to have wheels built for it, so any impure packages will require the presence of the build tools, and they may be broken at any time so the user is
encouraged to only install such packages in a virtual environment.

title: Three options exist for such installations:

inline_content.Text: Three options exist for such installations:

title: Download compressed snapshot, most online version control systems have the option to download a compressed snapshot of the code. This can be downloaded manually and then installed with
pip install
c
path/to/downloaded/file
i
note that for most compression formats pip will handle unpacking to a cache area, etc.

inline_content.Text: Download compressed snapshot, most online version control systems have the option to download a compressed snapshot of the code. This can be downloaded manually and then installed with
note that for most compression formats pip will handle unpacking to a cache area, etc.

title: Let pip handle the download & install for you with:
pip install
c
URL/of/package/repository
i
- you may also need to use the
--trusted-host
c
--client-cert
c
and/or
--proxy
c
flags for this to work correctly, especially in a corporate environment. e.g:

flags for this to work correctly, especially in a corporate environment. e.g:

title: Clone the repository using
git
c
mercurial
c
or other acceptable tool,
preferably a DVCS tool,
i
and use
pip install
c
path/to/cloned/repo
i
- this will
both
b
process any requires.text file and perform the build and setup steps,
you can manually change directory to your cloned repository and run
i
pip install -r requires.txt
i
c
and then
i
python setup.py install
i
c
to get the same effect.
i
The big advantages of this approach is that while the initial clone operation may take longer than the snapshot download you can update to the latest with, in the case of git:
git pull origin master
c
and if the current version contains errors you can use
pip uninstall
c
package-name
i
then use
git checkout
c
commands to move back through the repository history to earlier version(s) and re-try.
